text.title: New Zealand Holiday Itinerary â€” Travel Costs, Things To Do & Best Places To Visit
text.p: [Music]
after wrapping up our reveal new zealand
video series we're left with a bit of a
bittersweet taste now that all the
action is over
but there is so much more to see and
experience in our home and little piece
of paradise tucked away in the pacific
ocean
in case you missed that series we spent
almost six weeks exploring the length of
new zealand in a camper van visiting
both the north and south islands
we road tripped ticked off all the
musters along the way and shared some
super underrated spots as well
23 videos spanning close to seven hours
of footage is a lot though so we've had
loads of requests for a video covering
the ultimate new zealand itinerary
wow so if you're not entirely sure where
to start for your research
or you forgot to take notes while you
were watching the series you've come to
the right place in this video we're
going to cover five key elements
transport covering our preference timing
and seasons the pros and cons
recommended route and overview of what
we recommend
specifics per location detailed
breakdown of places musters and
accommodation
and expenses sharing all of the costs in
one place
so this is a massive video in itself but
there's still absolutely no way we can
cover
everything so we're going to answer a
huge amount of questions and everything
that you need to know about new zealand
if you really want to go deeper into
some research and we're going to put
that all into an extensive guide
so if you are interested in that we are
going to start emailing people as things
progress
so click the link in the description
below and sign up to our mailing list
new zealand is the perfect road trip
country so that's our recommended way of
getting around and what we did
sure you can fly everywhere or take a
tour but going full van life instantly
became our favorite way to adventure so
that's what we'll focus on
if that's not your scene this video will
still be relevant though if you choose
to travel by car or book hotels along
the way
we hired the biggest campervan you could
rent a sixth berth which was over seven
metres long
there are loads of different companies
though the most common we saw were maui
for the premium
brits or apollo looked like a great
middle of the road option and juicy for
the cheapest solution
we were a bit worried about the driving
conditions in winter but you can request
snow chains which
fortunately or unfortunately depending
on how you look at it we didn't even
need owls
hashtag expected more snow and as long
as you're careful to drive to the
conditions you'll be fine
we'll share more on the cost category
later on but to fill up with diesel cost
about 80 new zealand dollars and that
gave us four to 450 kilometres to a tank
we spent about six weeks in total
traveling and we spent two of those
weeks in the north island and four of
them in the south
island with about two days on average
in each place i mean i've said what in
the past do i want to do it right
stay for a long time not everybody can
do that we think six weeks is a good
period of time but
it kind of felt like a good balance and
it wasn't too rushed but it gave us a
really good chance to
cover heaps of ground we hired our
campervan who we named aston from
auckland and dropped it off in
queenstown then flew back home
it pays to note that expenses vary from
season to season and because we avoided
the summer high season and went in the
middle of winter we managed to get some
awesome deals along the way
the positives of winter travel with risk
comes reward we definitely roll the dice
by traveling during the coldest wettest
months of the year but the major
drawcard for us was experiencing some of
the most
beautiful parts of the country with
hardly anybody else around
in terms of the cons winter travel
turned out to have way less negative
than we were anticipating
because the conditions were nowhere near
as bad as we were expecting
one thing that we did miss out on was
freedom camping it got into the minuses
overnight so we opted for powered sites
so we could plug in our heater and
charge all of our gear
we spent so long planning our trip stacy
said done so many hand-drawn
handwritten like notes and drawings and
maps and everything so we'll start off
by doing a bit of like a bird's-eye view
of what six weeks looked like
for us but we learnt so much along the
way also
so we'll kind of dig deep dive next
chapter into
yeah into a little bit more details
before we share our recommendations we
just want to take a quick minute to chat
about our friends at skillshare the
sponsor of this video
skillshare is an online learning
community for everyone whether you're a
beginner
pro dabbler or master they offer
unlimited access to thousands of classes
so you can pretty much
learn anything you can think of we
mentioned recently how helpful
illustrating in procreate was for the
maps that stace has been making for our
reveal nz series all
on our ipad pro on a recent binge we
found podcasting secrets how to start
your own podcast by nikayla from side
hustle pro and found it so interesting
we're really familiar with most kinds of
media but had absolutely no idea about
the steps to go through for setting up a
podcast
in particular using a podcast host for
uploading and distribution
so we're a lot closer now to actually
starting our own
an annual subscription is less than ten
dollars a month and once you join you
get unlimited access to take as many
classes
on as many subjects as you want and
they're all ad free as well
so if you're keen to explore some new
skills or get lost in some holiday
creativity the first 1000 people to use
the link in the description will get a
free trial of skillshare premium
membership
continuing on there's a specific reason
we think you should start in the north
and head south
so for us the south island was what we
kind of wanted to save for last we
wanted to save the best for last so we
started in the north and we slowly made
our way down
and as we got further south we started
discovering stuff that you know we
haven't really explored there much
so yeah that's why we did it that way if
you have the time or if you love beach
holidays the most we would highly
recommend heading north of auckland
first
the bay of islands has so many amazing
beaches and capriana is an iconic spot
at the very top of the north island
because we did that trip earlier in the
year we decided to head south instead
the coromandel rotorua and toppo are
must but this is where you have some big
decisions to make
we personally decided to head west
because we wanted to explore the
taranaki region but you also have the
option from toppo to continue south and
do the tongariro crossing or
head east towards hawke's bay which is
an area known for its vineyards we're
hoping to check out really soon
from new plymouth we headed further
south to wellington and took the blue
bridge ferry across depicted
the journey takes just over three hours
and is notorious for being a tough ride
for people who suffer from sea sickness
so
on a bad day you need to pack your seat
bands this was one of the few times we
actually got lucky with the weather
though and ended up with a smooth
sailing the entire way
definitely book a private cabin with an
ensuite though because it's only 40
dollars more
from pickton we headed to nelson abel
tasman and nelson lakes before heading
down the west coast
if we had more time we would have loved
to have worked in the east coast and the
likes of blenheim kaikoura and
christchurch
but that's another one of those
decisions where you need to commit to
one side or the other
after fox glacier and franz joseph we
traveled through the haas pass to wanaka
and went
off right a little bit here for good
reason we traveled away from our next
ops a bit to walk the huka valley track
at mount cook national park again
then over to the east coast for amaru
dunedin down the coast of the catlins
and eventually bluff
wrapping things up in queenstown was a
nice way to end the trip it's one of our
favorite places in the world
has amazing accommodation options and
definitely should not be missed
what an absolute beautiful way to start
the day it's so
nice i love it here it's just so
relaxing
okay so this is where we'll go way
deeper into each of the places that we
went to along with our recommendations
for how long to stay what you should do
what you should do differently and just
anything else that we think is really
important
yeah the coromandel is chill kiwi vibes
through and through
hot water beach top 10 campsite is the
perfect spot to just be able to walk
across to the main attraction
hot water beach certain parts of the
beach are naturally heated by mineral
water so we hired a spade from reception
and made our way to create our own
natural hot tub well at least that's
what the plan was until we saw how busy
it was
we were a day behind given our campervan
delays so missed a lot of what we would
have liked to have seen in the
coromandel it literally is a beach
holiday heaven
cathedral cove is a must do but
unfortunately we didn't quite get there
but we recommend
you do on the way to rotorua is hobiton
where we took a tour around the movie
set whether a lord of the rings and
hobbit fan
or not the tour was actually really cool
it's a really really beautiful little
village
if i was a hobbit i know exactly where
i'd be at we stayed at the top 10
holiday park which was a great call as
well because it's a premium property and
the facilities there
are awesome rotorua is the adventure
capital of the north island and the list
of things to do there is
absolutely endless the seaplane to the
hot pools was probably our favorite
experience but you can do everything
from going to secret spot pools
visiting waiatapu sliding in some
buggies
[Music]
[Applause]
oh my days shooting a gun
whitewater rafting zip lining luging
mountain biking do the tree walk it's
absolutely crazy how much is going on so
make sure you leave
a few days to get your action on there's
a decent amount of stuff going on in
toppo so it's worth checking out for a
day or two it was a quick stop for us
though because the weather wasn't great
and it was a pretty familiar holiday
meeting point for us as kids
hooker falls and the world's coolest
mcdonald's are a must though
and a snap or two in front of the isle
of toppo sign
again we stayed at the top 10 campsite
here but the facilities weren't as great
and the location wasn't ideal
there wasn't really anything in walking
distance on the way to new plymouth we
stopped at the three sisters in elephant
rock a bunch of epic formations on a
black sand beach
don't forget to check the tides before
you walk out there like we did
well we knew we had to but we actually
completely forgot and were fortunate to
get there just before it was too late
tide's coming right up now
we had planned to freedom camp there on
site for the first time but there was
zero cell service
limited facilities and it was freezing
so we decided to continue on to fitzroy
beach holiday park in new plymouth and
we're glad we did there's an amazing
bridge there that has views back up to
mount taranaki if it's a clear day a
hike around the mountain looks like it
would be epic to do but the visibility
was terrible for us so we left earlier
than expected
but it pays to have some time up your
sleeve just in case
we took some time off in wellington to
catch up with friends but there is so
much to do here and we didn't get the
chance to share
don't miss te papa museum in particular
take a walk around downtown
check out the waterfront and there's a
few great cafes with the view around
petoni as well
wellington is the jump off spot that
connects the north and south island
it's where we drove our camper van onto
the ferry which was surprisingly easy
actually
they loaded the bigger vehicles first so
we had more room to swing around
no need to reverse at all and then we
could drive off forward on the other
side
if you get good weather on the ferry
make sure you head outside and keep an
eye out for dolphins as you pass through
the queen charlotte sound
that part of new zealand is insanely
beautiful but often hard to reach
so the best chance for the views will be
as you arrive through the channel
hopefully not being sick from the motion
in the ocean
welcome to the sunniest part of the
country we both
absolutely love nelson and everything on
offer there
i'm so stoked the sun is out
and we get to explore nelson today i how
long have i been talking about this
place for
it's pretty much since i've known you
you've been like we should go to nelson
and i don't know why we just haven't
really got around to doing it it's only
a two hour drive from pickton and we
parked up at the tehuna beach kiwi
holiday park right on the water the next
day we went to cable bay adventure park
and took on one of the world's longest
flying foxes before going on a tour
around pix peanut butter world
home to the best peanut butter in the
world pro tip
order the granola bowl at the cafe and
thank us later it's one of the nicest
bowls we've ever had and we've spent a
lot of time in bali
in the wider nelson tasman area mapua
wharf is a hell yes
the perfect place to eat drink and spend
the afternoon in the sun
the smoking barrel for gourmet doughnuts
and machueca is also key
we stayed at the kai teri theta
campgrounds right on the beachfront and
was probably our favorite beach spot of
the entire trip
we spent the first night in aston then
moved up to an apartment so we could do
some washing and catch up on some life
admin
from here you can launch up into abel
tasman national park new zealand's
smallest
and arguably best national park
it honestly feels like you could be on a
tropical island the water isn't that
clear
we did a tour that was a kayak hike
cruise combo and to be fair one day is
not enough in abel tasman so we
recommend more like three or four if you
like nature
beaches and hiking you could walk for
three days straight and still not see
everything
a day trip to anatoky salmon farm to
catch our own lunch and check out pupu
springs was absolutely worth the winding
roads of takaka hill
we'd heard about the nelson lakes before
but hadn't intended to spend any time
there
but on our way to the west coast we took
a slower route to get a look and
instantly knew we'd made a bad call
the lakes are stunning and it would have
been awesome to even just spend a night
and take some kind of tour or take a
walk and explore so take that into
consideration
the wild west coast has a reputation of
being new zealand's most rugged raw and
untouched landscapes with dark volcanic
black sand beaches the ruthless
coastline and terrible weather it's
quite the experience
our first stop on the west coast was
tauranga bay an area known for its seal
colony and being a bit more of a chill
and beachy spot we stayed at one of the
out the bay
tiny homes owned by some of our amazing
subscribers there's a few key things to
see down the main roads of the west
coast so we stopped at the punakaiki
pancake rocks which is a must
this is impressive i didn't expect it to
quite be this good
yeah our timing was off a little bit to
see the blowhole though because you have
to get there at the right time for the
tide
look that up if it's something you'd
consider seeing but for us it was part
of a longer day and the time we arrived
just happened to be determined by other
factors
in hokitika we stayed at a campsite
called shining star beachfront
accommodation
the best part about it was how close it
was to the beach and the fact that there
was a cat and llamas on site hanging
around
the facilities weren't actually that
great though we'd planned to go and do
the hokitika gorge walk but there was
loads of construction at the time it
would not stop raining and we needed a
day to catch up on some editing but it
totally looks like it would have been
worth the visit
next stop franz josef we stayed at
rainforest retreat in a deluxe tree hut
which was insanely cool especially after
living out of a camper van for so long
it's no wonder we got so many messages
from people saying we should check it
out
there are heaps of hikes in the area so
we picked a different one each day and
got different vantage points of france
joseph glacier each time
that didn't even take long no that was
like there was like 15 seconds after we
finished that
we only got to do about a quarter of the
walk to the terminal face because the
track was closed and that happens often
from what we're told but there are still
loads of other options in the area that
still have great views
we spent the following three days
waiting out the rain at fox glacier top
10 campsite which was pretty decent
we had to hang around so that we could
do the heli hike and we are so glad that
we left that leeway because it turned
out to be the highlight of our whole
trip
good stuff babe
we drove there three or four days in a
row to be told it wasn't happening and
even then
things went down to the wire when it did
by being on final call we got all geared
up had a safety briefing and it wasn't
until we were at the heli landing pad
that we got the all clear that we were
gonna fly up to the glacier
we got two solid hours of hiking sliding
and exploring on the glacier
before the clouds started rolling in
again and we had to fly back down
an hour early even with an hour less it
didn't feel rushed and it turned out to
be one of the most memorable moments of
the entire trip
looking on a map hookah valley track is
not very far from fox glacier
at all but the crazy thing is just how
far you have to travel by
road to actually reach it it's almost
six hours to drive
the whole way around so we left fox

stop at lake matheson before continuing
on through the house pass
and settled up in wanaka to break up the
trip for the night
a popular stop during the house pass
drive is the blue pools so leave enough
time to check that out
wanaka is also an awesome little town
that's sometimes overlooked in favor of
queenstown
but we were down there early this year
for a wedding so didn't spend any time
exploring ourselves but a day or two in
the area is probably worth it
it's early my body is not designed for
this
we woke up crazy early the next morning
to drive the three hours to the hooker
valley track which is the best walk that
we've personally done in new zealand
it's a three-hour hike that gets you to
the base of mount cook new zealand's
tallest mountain
we've done this hike twice now and it
was just as incredible the second time
and well worth the silly o'clock morning
to get there
originally we'd planned to freedom camp
at the white horse hill campsite right
out front but again with no power and

we just decided to soldier on to amarama
for the night quickly
next stop moraki via omaru this is where
we nearly smashed into a bridge
so if you're driving a camper van
towards the victorian precinct please be

a few of you guys recently let us know
that it got crashed into by a truck a

blocking off the street all together now
once we got over the shock of almost
losing our roof we discovered that omaru
might just be one of the quirkiest
places in new zealand
it's given me give me weird feelings
mixed emotions as to where we actually
are
there's castle blue penguins although we
didn't get to see them
a street with a real uk vibe steampunk
museums and statues everywhere you look
thirty minutes south is modaki an area

we did some research and realized low

grab some breakfast up at the cafe near

they form over time in the cliff walls
and then roll down and settle on the

fleur's seafood restaurant is a must do

also dane highly recommends you try a

this was our first time in dunedin a

that's a bit of a stretch in terms of
looks but the scottish connection goes
back generations dunedin is home to
baldwin street the steepest street
in the world
wales recently tried to steal the title

we ain't having that and someone got out

tunnel beach is definitely worth a visit
as well the walk down is absolutely
stunning but be prepared for the walk
back
up because it is a little bit of a

facilities of the trip and the location
was kind of okay but it's kind of
limited options in dunedin
this is a good place to hit the bars
though and get your drink on if that's
your kind of vibe
located in the southeast corner of the

you don't often hear too much about
possibly because of how remote it is we
struggle to find much in the way of

cafes and people to be honest possibly
the season
may be covered or maybe it was just the
poor weather predicted for the next few
days
first stop was nugget point lighthouse
one of the oldest lighthouses in the

because of the scattered rocks that
looked like nuggets of gold off the

this is nuggies yeah that makes sense
now
we also visited purakaunui falls curio
bay
slope point and we're fascinated by the

forest
frozen in time on the beach we stayed at

a penguin hunt but the chances of seeing

are slim surely i've been hunting for

for five weeks now so rare that we had
zero chance of ever seeing it but that's
just our luck and we hope yours is

you can't go that far south and not stop

nor is a visit complete without trying

i have never genuinely i have never

on an unnecessary amount of oysters fosh

but it was absolutely delicious and that

originally we planned to stay a bit

so we made a decision to tackle the two

back up to queenstown and spend a little

if you're short on time like we were on

it's not cheap and it's always busy but

a really good mid-range option is my pad

no on-site parking so keep that in mind
the most luxurious places that we've

amisfield rata fergburger

drink explore and definitely get a

five hundred dollars for transport
related stuff specifically
three thousand four hundred of that was
for the van rental and the road users
charges that you have to pay at the end

diesel is cheap though and we only spent

and then the flights back to auckland

on average forty dollars was about the

costs

and then 400 plus was the most expensive
